title: How to See if Flowers Lean Towards the Sun

steps.headline: Gather your materials.
steps.description: You will need 3 cups, soil, tape, a marker, paper, a shoebox, seeds, aluminum foil, 1 straw, and water. Organize your materials on a table or desk for easy use. You can pick any seed. Some good options are corn, lima bean, or radish. You can substitute a shoebox for another medium-sized box.

steps.headline: Label the side of each cup.
steps.description: Use the marker to label each cup. You can use the labels “A, B, C” or “1, 2, 3”. These labels will help you identify the plants throughout your experiment.

steps.headline: Line your shoebox with foil.
steps.description: First, remove and discard the lid and 1 side of the shoebox. This will allow light to enter from an angle. Next, line the remainder of the shoebox with aluminum foil. This prevents it from getting wet when you water the plants. Place the shoebox on a windowsill or on a table in front of a window.

steps.headline: Fill each cup half full of soil.
steps.description: Be sure to use the same kind of soil in each cup. Leave the soil loose. If you pack it too tightly, the seeds will not be able to grow well.

steps.headline: Plant the seeds.
steps.description: Follow the planting instructions on the seed package. These instructions will differ depending on what plant you choose. For example, some seeds might need to be covered by 1 inch (2.5 cm) of soil, while others may need to be covered by 3 inches (7.6 cm) of soil.

steps.headline: Water each plant.
steps.description: Turn a faucet or spigot on so that a small steady stream of water is flowing. Move the cup back and forth under the water until the soil looks wet. Do not overwater the soil. It should just be damp to the touch.

steps.headline: Place the cups in the box by the window.
steps.description: The cups need to be side by side in the shoe box. This is how the light will be controlled for the experiment. Always keep the same cups in the same place. Moving them around will mess up your results. Once you place the cups in the box, you will not need to remove them. The seeds will sprout, and the plants will grow facing the direction they choose.

steps.headline: Make a shoot cap.
steps.description: The shoot cap will prevent light from shining on the tip of the plant. The cap can be made by surrounding the top ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of a straw with aluminum foil. The cap should be a cylinder that is ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) tall and has a covered top.

steps.headline: Make base caps.
steps.description: Base caps will not cover the top of the plant, but will cover the stem instead. To make this kind of cap, you should wrap aluminum foil around a straw. Do not cover the top or bottom of the straw. The base cape should be a cylinder with no covered top or bottom, and should be roughly ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) long.

steps.headline: Let the plants grow.
steps.description: The plants will need to sprout before you cap them. This will take different amounts of time for different plants. Once the plants sprout, you should let them grow to ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) tall.

steps.headline: Cap the plants.
steps.description: Once the plants have grown about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm), you need to put the assigned caps on them. Place a shoot cap on plants in cup A (or 1). Use base caps for plants in cup B (or 2). Place no caps on plants in cup C (or 3). The third cup is a control group.

steps.headline: Analyze the plant growth.
steps.description: As you monitor the plants over the next days and weeks, make note of which flowers lean toward the sun and which ones lean away from the sun. The flowers in cup A will likely grow straight up. The flowers in cups B and C will likely lean toward the sun. This happens because the light is detected at the top of the shoot, and the flower grows in the direction of the light. When you cover the top of the shoot with a shoot cap, the plant cannot detect the light and grows straight up. Note that light-oriented growth is called "phototropism." Scientists have found that the plants can “bend” toward light because cells on one side of the plant stem elongate, a process regulated by a plant hormone called auxin.
